review.title: “Great name and reputation, undervalued emplyees”
review.pros: Pros – Great name and reputation, and they do churn out a lot of interesting, award-winning projects. R/GA is a great name to have on your resume
review.cons: Cons – R/GA has gotten too large for its own good. It makes you feel like a tiny, expendable cog in a huge system. This has also made it hard for people to reach out to higher management to discuss anything related to your career or other matters. It definitely got clunky. For instance, you could get stuck on a boring account for years and it would be very hard to get yourself heard and moved to a different account to keep learning and growing. That can take its toll on your portfolio, as well.Office space is quite nondescript and depressing, and there is very little sense of integration and community, despite the open layout. Mostly people silently starting and their computer screens.It is also incredibly difficult to get promoted, or even get a raise. I have worked there for 5 years without a single actual raise worth speaking of, even when I got a change in title. And I know many people around me who are in the same position—many of which are resigning or looking forward to do so. This phenomenon has more to do with office politics than the work of their employees. I have done my share of 60+ hour weeks and weekends and felt very little acknowledgment or appreciation—and forget about time or monetary compensation. They definitely need to work harder to make their employees feel valued and have their efforts and dedication acknowledged.On a similar note, there is very little mentorship, coaching or guidance. Many times, I felt like I was being left to my own devices or out of the loop altogether, with very little knowledge of what's going on internally or with the client.Oh, and people with big egos abound and can make your experience there really, really miserable.
review.advice-to-management: No, I would not recommend this company to a friend

review.title: “Lacks leadership and talent management”

Mostly digital banners, barely any mobile or social. Lackluster work that doesn't win any awards, led by ECD's that are clueless about digital (they come from traditional/branding)Long hours. Lack of time management leads to long nights and weekends which burn out the team and have caused many to leave in less than 6 months
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Fire the senior managers and start fresh with a new team that's vested in the agency and talent

Managers are not doing a good job of managing and growing the careers of those they are responsible for.There's no recognition or compensation despite the long hours, nights and weekends spent to deliver excellent work. The staff feels unappreciated and unrecognized, and while senior management is aware of this, nothing has been done to address it.Those that tried to inject fun, culture and life into this oddly quiet office are quickly discouraged, shut down or pushed out.The vibe is weird, you sense there's something wrong, but can't exactly put your finger on it until you've started working here. Do not work here if you want a career in digital advertising. Work here if all you want to do is create banners that nobody clicks on.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Take some management courses and learn how to effectively manage and communicate with people. You are rock stars on your own, but terrible when it comes to managing talent - you need to invest in learning how to manage talent at all levels.Be more energetic and enthusiastic in order to motivate and excite people. Your lack of energy is disappointing and uninspiring. Stop treating it like a job that pays the bills and start showing some passion in your work.Socialize and hang out with the rest of the staff in order to get to know them

review.title: “Slightly Disenchanted”

review.cons: Cons – 1. R/GA will make your resume stand out, but if you don't gain the portfolio to back it up...2. A lot of egos and hacks too. Some of the management seems to have become friendly with the right people and move up to where they are today, yet they are horrible managers that are severely outdated. They tend to float on the work that's actually done by the lower level creatives by taking all the credit for it since they provided "direction." It's really sad as the lower level creatives become disenchanted by the whole experience at R/GA, thinking that they busted their butts to get the job (very tough interview process) only to find that they're stuck doing routine, uninspiring work on an account they have no interest in for a manager that they can't even look up to or learn from.3. Ask for the money you want to be making from the start. Don't low-ball yourself, or you will be placed on a low-ball salary track that's hard to break free from.4. The opportunities are present to work on important, portfolio building projects providing you are on the right account. But you have to pick your battles: A) Sign your life away and work on one of the big thinking, award winning, sexy accounts OR B) Choose to have somewhat of a life by working on mundane accounts. It is R/GA and you will have a hard time balancing work/life no matter what account you're on, but you have maybe an 80/20 rather than a 150/0 if you work on the boring accounts as opposed to the exciting accounts.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Make more of an effort to ensure your employees are satisfied with the work they're doing and the account they're on, rather than just finding an opening somewhere and sticking anybody in there to fill a gap. Evaluate managers with more scrutiny...sometimes managers take advantage of their lower level employees by taking all the credit for their hard work. Weed out the dinosaurs that manage to coast by and promote the lower level employees who have consistently been doing great, cutting edge work.

review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – The management is fine, from what I've seen so far the leaders are great. Obviously, there are a few bad apples and I think wrong hiring decisions were made.

review.title: “Do the time, move on”
review.pros: Pros – Name recognitionAccess to high ranking individuals client sideGood opportunity to find a mentor when starting outTalented peopleWork here for a little bit and watch your Linkedin blow up. Makes getting the job you really want easier.Good parties
review.cons: Cons – It is no longer a design firm. Most decisions are driven by money and the integrity of everyone's work is suffering as a result.Lots of people competing for limited promotion spots. Senior management however, seems to be adding letters to their titles on a daily basisNot much of a challenge on retainer accounts. They tend to hire really smart people and make them do production work. A lot of creatives burn out quickly due to the assembly line nature of the place.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Promote internally moreFix the place up, the main building is ok, but this is not a creative environmentLet people move around accounts more, so many people are leaving due to burnoutDo something innovativeStop hiding behind the bureaucracy telling us that you can't do things for us because of x y and z

review.title: “Agency with very clever people”
review.pros: Pros – - good clients- great team- intelligent
review.cons: Cons – - bad work space- bad hours- advertizing

review.title: “Satisfied, but demanding more out of management”
review.pros: Pros – Gifted talent, fun work place, great pay, great perks, great name. You will feel compelled to devote yourself to your team, since everyone works their tail off.Great place to learn how to manage projects with a lean and mean team. Great gut check for those who think they know their stuff. R/GA does a great job of weeding out those who just cant cut it.
review.cons: Cons – The work is a little dry since senior management's main goal is getting a larger retainer. Think about it like this - If I am calling the shots on a huge account, it isn't my concern about whether the team is happy with the work, since that isn't how my success is measured, it is more like...How big can we get? How much can we get? What profit can be turned due to running lean?
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Read your incoming employees resume's. Don't think of everyone as a number, or a gap fill. Give people the opportunity to work on projects that will satisfy their need for innovation while you take care of the tactical delivery of what is called for by the clients business.LISTEN!!!!

review.title: “Never a dull moment.”
review.pros: Pros – Fast pace; interesting clients; mostly smart co-workers; entrepreneurial atmosphere; great coffee bar; humor appreciated; great team work; good place to learn a lot fast
review.cons: Cons – Long hours; often a lack of clear direction from the top; inadequate number of staff often assigned to gargantuan tasks
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Find people for the top spots that actually have experience running a company of this size. Actually walk the office and come see us sometimes; try to know your employees.

review.title: “Great place to learn and grow.”
review.pros: Pros – Opportunities for career advancement & growth.Learn about digital advertising at its best.People are pretty knowledgeable in their respective disciplines.
review.cons: Cons – Digital advertising isn't always cool. Lots of banner ads and email templates.Every team is completely different. So moving from one to another is sometimes a culture shock.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Keep it up.

review.title: “work hard but produce good stuff”
review.pros: Pros – R/GA provides a chance to work with super talented people and world class clients. They are innovative and emphasize quality of work
review.cons: Cons – the hours can be long, and many of the clients are frustrating. since r/ga is a great reputation, clients can expect a lot.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – provide more feedback to employees. manage expectations of clients better and push back when necessary. monitor morale. and fix phones.

review.title: “i'm learning something new everyday”
review.pros: Pros – work with really talented folks
review.cons: Cons – only get to work on one account at a time
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – wish i had more mentoring

review.title: “Diverse, multi-disciplined, yet incredibly collaborative.”
review.pros: Pros – Lets start with the reasons stated above: it has a fabulous pool of talent: you find people who are just great at thinking, conceiving, and making: simultaneously. And people are very good at understanding what the other person brings to the table. Unlike other agencies where the loudest person gets ahead, R/GA is setup in such a way that the wisest and the most talented have the ability to steer the conversation. To the major extent, I would say that this level of openness and collaboration is inspired by the people at the helm: BG, N-Law, and the leads of the range of disciplines.We have some of the best clients the industry has to offer!The work is consistently good.It keeps attracting great talent.There is a warmth to the agency that you dont find at other places.People are happy, and that says a lot.Every project is approached like a "start-up".
review.cons: Cons – Time is a really really precious commodity at R/GA.Because of the sudden and unexpected growth, the agency culture is taking a bit of a beating.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Give people the freedom to create outside the boundaries of business.

review.title: “good place for go-getters”
review.pros: Pros – - really good at rewarding hard/persistent workers- good mentoring system- the people are really smart, talented, awesome, and well-rounded
review.cons: Cons – - communication isn't always great- there's a split between system/platform design and the advertising people- there's a lot of talk but not always a lot of action- not creatively driven - very production-led
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – celebrate creative. be less "responsible" and cautious about interesting concepts. less talk, more doing. address agency issues head-on and discuss them internally with everyone before they become bigger problems.

review.title: “Fun job”
review.pros: Pros – Fun Beer Hard work cheese
review.cons: Cons – Long hours stressful clients cheese
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Work harder

review.title: “Good People, Difficult Advancement”
review.pros: Pros – Smart, talented, and intelligent people. Generous vacation time. Decent benefits package. High profile client work. Bike racks and picnic tables in courtyard.
review.cons: Cons – Difficult to advance beyond a certain point. Difficulty moving around the company (between accounts). Less than satisfactory salary increases. Offices near the Port Authority and tourist hotels.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Work with your employees to find solutions with the clients rather than sacrifice your employees to meet every whim and demand of the client.

review.title: “Lots of hours and responsibility, little pay or recognition”
review.pros: Pros – Lots of responsibility and exposure to complex business problems. Freedom to run your projects as you see fit - no one micro-manages you (or even manages you).
review.cons: Cons – Little pay, tiny raises. Very little support or awareness of what you do day in and day out - unless something goes wrong. Hard to escalate problems and grab the attention of management. Even harder to get help solving problems.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Consider people's skill set and interest before placing them on an account; support the teams that are working long hours day in and day out - not just once a year during their review

review.title: “Great place to work, some tough competition”
review.pros: Pros – The people here are very smart, motivated and talented. If you get on a good account, you'll work with some of the best in the business.
review.cons: Cons – There's a small group of top talent at the top that get to work on the best pitches and projects. It's tough to break in and prove yourself sometimes.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Creatives crave change. Although it's good for a client to have a dedicated creative team, it's not great for the creatives themselves. Moving people around more often and diversifying the work would be greatly apriciated.

review.title: “headline”
review.pros: Pros – smart people great use of tech
review.cons: Cons – too much turnover not enough cash
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – none

review.title: “Good company but some awkward processes”
review.pros: Pros – R/GA has a very relaxed atmosphere, with great people. Middle to upper management (some at least) are willing to listen and address concerns as necessary. The pay is good, and the roster of clients is impressive.
review.cons: Cons – Some of the processes can be tiresome, and not as efficient as they could be in this day and age. Also, the company is very design centric, leaving tech with very little say sometimes in the final product.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – To be more flexible and modern (i.e agile) and to promote forward thinking as well as productivity tools and methods/patterns

review.title: “R/GA San Francisco - 360 Degree Design”
review.pros: Pros – Variety of projects from big to small on variety of subjectsGreat project mobility not to much not too little, every few month ability to participate in something new weather it is brainstorming, researching, sketching, ideation or productionGreat people: smart, international, humble, pleasantSmart and respectful managementWonderful work location
review.cons: Cons – A lot of work is done with the New York office, long distance, time difference and alternative work culture take effort.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – San Francisco management - greatNew York management - be more open minded and have trust

review.title: “Not a bad place to meet some talented people”
review.pros: Pros – some very talented and smart people, small account teams and little bureaucracy mean you have an opportunity to make a big difference for your account
review.cons: Cons – if you're stuck on a bad account can feel like a sweatshop, quality of work, talent, and mangement on teams is uneven
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – management seems disconnected from the day-to-day life of those who really work in the trenches there

review.title: “Great place to learn and get coffee”
review.pros: Pros – The culture tends to be focused much more on getting work done but doesn't get all "serious business" about the work being done. Fairly casual atmosphere and you can come in past 9 and no one will bat an eye so long as you get your share of work done. They also have a nice, cheap coffee bar inside the building so you can keep focused on what you're doing and stay caffeinated.
review.cons: Cons – The focus on results tends to also mean that the less monumental achievements get overlooked. At times there will be situations where producers or non-technical people drop the ball on key issues, and communication between different disciplines/teams in the company can be rather slow or unclear. Overall, most of these problems aren't too bad but pretty par for the course.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – A greater general technical competence of staff such as analytics, producers, and designers would greatly aid communication and help drive better decision-making throughout the company.

review.title: “Some of the smartest people in the business”
review.pros: Pros – It's a big company but it acts like a small one in that it can change quickly to the marketplace, adding new capabilities and finding the right people to run them.
review.cons: Cons – Sometimes a lack of transparency from the senior leadership when it comes to why some policies are implemented. I think it's due to being beholden to IPG...
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Understand that most of the people at R/GA are talented enough to find jobs just about anywhere, and though the economy is tough, keeping people happy and secure is a way to make sure everyone STAYS at R/GA once the economy inevitably picks up.

review.title: “There's Nike, and then everything else.”
review.pros: Pros – Pay was good in comparison to most competitors. I know the Nike team is always insane and relatively unpleasant if you want work-life balance. But since I wasn't on Nike, I worked pretty consistent hours.
review.cons: Cons – R/GA isn't a bad place to work but I certainly did not enjoy it. I worked on a non-Nike team and it was a total waste of my time. My manager(s) were fine, but all of my co-workers were definitely incompetent. I was lied to about the work I was going to be doing, I was lied to about my benefits and PTO time. So... very bad HR. They basically told me anything to get me hired on and after a short period of time I decided I needed to work in a more professional, higher caliber office.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Stop hiring bench warmers. There's no sense in increasing head count when the heads have nothing in them...

review.title: “If you have a chance, suck it up and stay there a while. I'tll pay off.”
review.pros: Pros – R/GA basically propells your carrer like no other place. They just won "Digital Agency of the year" so, just to have R/GA on your resume will help you out a lot in life. And through a number of big clients, it's usually a place that is able like no other to do new and exciting things
review.cons: Cons – Because it is so big, it's a bit hard to manage talend. Everything has to be packed into little boxes, and that might not exploit one's full potential.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Creative people need creative jobs. They can't just be making the same thing all day long

review.title: “R/GA is a great place to work.”
review.pros: Pros – Solid company. Great clients. Pushing the envelope. Interesting projects. Fairly flexible schedule. All in all, I like the vibe at R/GA.
review.cons: Cons – Sometimes it can get a little too big, and one can feel lost in the shuffle. I think it's definitely a place where you will likely need to make yourself visible in order to advance. I also feel like sometimes the projects could be a little more efficiently run.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – I would say, be sure to examine the efficiency of the projects at hand. Sometimes, with many people on a project, things can get a little out of hand, causing extra work to be done that is not needed. Making sure everyone is always on the same page can help mitigate these issues.

review.title: “Great place to work, but not enough variety.”
review.pros: Pros – The work environment is quite laid back. The employees are great. The work is generally top notch. Compensation is very fair. Great parties.
review.cons: Cons – Account structure means most people work on only one account at a time, so variety of work is lacking. Somewhat difficult to be promoted from within.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Let more employees help out on pitchwork. Give employees more flexibility to work outside of their home account.

review.title: “Put in your time, build your book and reap the benefits at your next gig”
review.pros: Pros – From a strictly professional standpoint, if you work at R/GA, especially in a creative capacity, you will have the chance to do great work, build your book, and win some awards. Also, you'll get to work with truly innovative people that if you are lucky, you will touch base with down the road on bigger and better projects.
review.cons: Cons – If you want to have no personal life than work for R/GA. The hours are crazy, they expect you to commit every fiber of your being, personal life be damned. A lot of people get burned out and there is a sense of smugness in some of the people there. If you didn't go to the right school or aren't into the latest, micro-trend you might get looked down on.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Provide a better environment for personal improvement, everyone can get better with a little guidance, it shouldn't always be sink or swin.

review.title: “There's R/GA Nike, and then there's the rest of R/GA”
review.pros: Pros – The work can be interesting and innovative. The people are smart and fun to work with. There's a surprisingly small number of ego-centric jerks, and most people are humble and down to earth.Your checks won't bounce! Get on the right account and you'll fill your resume up with awards.
review.cons: Cons – The buildings are in really bad shape and the work areas are depressing, dirty and sweat-shop-like. Once you get placed on an account, it's very hard to move. A lot of the work is slogging through very dry, low level pages of corporate websites. Not particularly focused on building memorable consumer experiences.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – The company is pretty big but it feels like it's still trying to be run like a small shop.

review.title: “A place to learn and develop your skills... if you are self-motivated and has a liberal mindset.”
review.pros: Pros – Cutting edge projects in the field and a top notch technical team makes R/GA a great place for techies with an art sensibility to develop their skills. The company's technical hierarchy is very flat and the enforcement of positions almost non-existent. That means that you could be doing anything at any time and while most work is related to your core activity, you will be doing a multitude of things in a project - from physics motion development to xml cut and pasting. The work environment is very liberal and people are expected to take responsibility for their work and run with it. There is minimal oversight, but help is always available if sought out.
review.cons: Cons – Too much freedom does have its drawback. Lack of oversight and loose management generates a lot of extra hours and an extremely high workload. Weekend and/or late night work is pretty much a constant. Work tends to flow without much process and there is quite a bit of confusion on communication and client relations. I repeat another reviewer's comments that because people are expected to take responsibility for a project on their own, when that sometimes doesn't happen, a project can fail just out of owner, or someone has to pick up the extra load to make it happen. In the end of the day, because little oversight doesn't provide good info for management, people get rewarded by perceived instead of real competence - and it is not uncommon for quantity of work gets confused with quality and personal politics to trump excellence on promotions.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Get information flowing up and down. Don't just expect things to happen and take action to promote communication. Start striving for productivity and optimization instead of brute force to get more of the quality work R/GA is known for out.

review.title: “R/GA is the cat's meow”
review.pros: Pros – The talent at R/GA is phenomenal. There are a lot of interesting things happening at once and at times can be a little overwhelming to keep track of things that are happening across the company. It's growing rapidly but isn't getting out of hand. Kris Kiger, VP of Visual Designer is awesome and very personable as well as all of the other upper management, Creative Directors included.
review.cons: Cons – It's a fast paced environment, and sometimes you can get lost in the mix because the company is growing so fast so if you want to expand your career, you have to speak up for yourself and voice your opinions. Also, the company is spread out into three buildings so it's hard to converse and get to know other coworkers outside of your existing team.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – I think the Senior Management does a fantastic job in keeping the entire company up to date, so I'm not sure what feedback I have to give. They are very motivating and care for the people who work there. They care about the quality of work, unlike some places I have worked for in the past. It shows through their portfolio and client list.

review.title: “Resign, get rehired with a huge promotion, repeat”
review.pros: Pros – The work is very interesting and R/GA has many high profile clients. The people are also extremely talented and one of the best things about R/GA is being able to work w/ these people (although I would exclude a good portion of the recent hires from this description). Also, the company compensates people very well as far as salary and health benefits go.
review.cons: Cons – There is very little recognition for regular, everyday employees and the tiny bit that exists often times gets directed at the wrong people/person. Also, employees ping pong back and forth between here and other ad agencies. When people quit, you know that you are going to see them working again at R/GA again within a year or so, and that somehow they are going to end up being your boss. Another thing is that the work day can be a very long day indeed, much more than the standard 8 hours.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – The work environment is really overcrowded and this problem should be more seriously addressed.

review.title: “Mostly great work and smart people striving for excellence, although sometimes fighting for recognition.”
review.pros: Pros – Mostly highly creative people and a desire to create excellent work. (As the company has grown, they've been forced to hire less talented individuals across the board.) There are some very, very smart people that can be found there.
review.cons: Cons – Compared to other companies, management doesn't display much concern for employees. There's a bit of a sense of being a piece of the machine. Additionally, R/GA has many shifting visions of itself and doesn't do a great job of communicating this within the company, or training people to succeed.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Pay more attention to your employees. Set people up for success. Reign in the dysfunctional infighting at a senior mgmt level.

review.title: “Great at work, could be better at business”
review.pros: Pros – The company has a very flat hierarchy, the team structure on accounts is very much like working a free lance environment. You are very much responsible for your own time. The roles of people tend to evolve organically out their specific interests related to their discipline which can be very powerful with a highly proactive group of people together on one team. The atmosphere is very causal and relaxed no hard hours, you are just expected to get your work done on time and on scope.
review.cons: Cons – The lack of structure can also be a weakness if a group comes together where no one champions the project and if individuals responsible for their discipline do not own their work. We also seem to have staffing issues, we can never seem to fully staff and account. There are also issues regarding properly scoping and scheduling projects, rarely is appropriate amounts of time given to programming, although I've seen improvements as of late.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – budget, staff, and schedule better

review.title: “R/GA- full of smart, passionate people!”
review.pros: Pros – It's exremely innovative,there is a lack of ego compared to most agencies, full of smart/passionate people, and the work is diverse. It's an entrepreneurial environment that provides individuals with the autonomy to make things happen.
review.cons: Cons – The Agency has grown extremely fast in the past few years which can make for a chaotic environment. The growth has slowed so there is more process being implemented than in the past.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – R/GA is a fairly flat structure, which can be one of it's greatest strengths, but I would encourage Sr Management to find a way to weave in some layers that allow for more growth.

review.title: “R/GA -- an exciting company, a chaotic environment”
review.pros: Pros – R/GA does great work, win many awards (mostly design and advertizing awards) and does come cutting edge work.They are in a good situaltion which has created job stability and growth.Technically there are oportunites to try many different things.
review.cons: Cons – Because most of the executives never leave, opportunities for growth only appear as new positions appear.Also, there are many postitions (though not all) where people are expected to work unreasonable hours.Often partly due to client expectations partly due to internal culture project schedules are compressed. Tech, on the end of the schedules is often impacted when creatives can't deliver ontime.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – It would be great of Management was more strategic, and communicated and followed though on those stragegies. It often feels like they are reacting, not planning.s\

review.title: “R/GA has its weaknesses but it also has potential for extraordinary growth.”
review.pros: Pros – Compensation and benefits are generous. The company generally is a good place to work and the people are easy going and friendly.
review.cons: Cons – The structure of the company is largely beginning to reflect traditional agency influence. The atmosphere of the company does not promote strong creative or interactive work. Advancement is generally time based and ability is not recognized or rewarded. Personal career development is normally a outside of job activity. Also people are viewed more as resources and treated as production pipelines rather than organic teams.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – I feel the influx of people from traditional agencies is hurting the company greatly. There is a growing number of employees whose work is not proportionate to their salaries these are usually director level hires who do more management than good work.

review.title: “R/GA”
review.pros: Pros – Great company, highly innovative, feels like a family.
review.cons: Cons – Hours are a bit insane and clients will be taken on before a team is assembled.
review.advice-to-management: Yes, I would recommend this company to a friend – I'm optimistic about the outlook for this company

review.title: “Great team. They hear you, even if you are an intern.”
review.pros: Pros – Advanced technology and always willing to implement innovative ideas.
review.cons: Cons – Working long hours sometimes, but i think thats common.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Nothing much to say.

review.title: “Nice.”
review.pros: Pros – Great Talent on the stage. You always find new technologies or new experiences.
review.cons: Cons – Complex to share your work internally.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – ---

review.title: “Very solid, learned a ton as an intern”
review.pros: Pros – Worked with some amazing interaction designersLoved the office atmosphere, really chillGot to do solid work as an intern, was pretty impressed
review.cons: Cons – Didn't get to see the client side of an agency, although I requested toIt's hard to contribute anything meaningful with such a strong team already. Not a con, I learned a ton. Just saying the value is in education and experience, not necessarily as much in creation/contribution.A lot of pitch deck assembly.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Doing a fine job overall.

review.title: “Hard work, but worth the effort”
review.pros: Pros – Good clients, exciting projects, amazing people, talented design and tech departments.
review.cons: Cons – Production can be weak with clients, work / life balance needs improving.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Let the teams mature, less pressure from above, more time for learning and reflection.

review.title: “A great place to work!”
review.pros: Pros – R/GA has only continued to evolve in my time here and it's definitely a place where you can make your own path and work with both great clients and team members.
review.cons: Cons – At times it's find your own way, but that can and should be flipped to an opportunity for growth.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – somewhat better coordinated communications could be better ... there's a fair bit of crowd-sourced information gathering, though that's certainly not unique to R/GA.

review.title: “World class team”
review.pros: Pros – The people. Some of the best & brightest in the adv/marketing industryLive & breathe tech & UXStrong offerings - Strategy to prod dev to marketing communicationGlobal offices really work well together (and support each other)
review.cons: Cons – Big & highly politicalUnderstaffedQuality suffers
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Focus on qualityKeep hiring world class experts

review.title: “Great experience”
review.pros: Pros – Smart people, great environment, relaxed community
review.cons: Cons – Long hours and sometimes inefficient communication

review.title: “Handicapped”
review.pros: Pros – The chance to work with very talented people, very good accounts and build your portfolio.
review.cons: Cons – So big and so many people that most of the time your work will go unnoticed. Most of the time your success depends on having a good or bad relationship with the leads.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Try not to dumb down the experience and positions of your employees.

review.title: “Very professional, high global level”
review.pros: Pros – Build your experience with the best of an international team
review.cons: Cons – A dull client portfolio and lack of hierarchy - every senior staff on the same level.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – More time spent organizing stuff around is greatly needed.

review.title: “quality of work doesn't match reputation”
review.pros: Pros – -paid well-company has a great reputation which helps a lot with your career-good insight and experience into business marketing techniques
review.cons: Cons – -a lot of big egos, favoritism.-management imagines they are still a cool small start-up company and are oblivious to the employees who do the work which make the company successful. they seem to sometimes resent newer employees for ruining their small,cool,rebel self-image yet are happy to reap the benefits of running a large company-didn't keep promises. I volunteered to do extra work in exchange to be put on a better project, got a pat on the back, and then they promptly forgot about me- you don't get any credit for doing good work unless you are senior. however you can also easily slack off and you won't get fired.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Pay more attention to employees. Reward talented employees by putting them on more meaningful work.

review.title: “A company that has grown too fast and doesn't know how to handle or take care of its employees”
review.pros: Pros – A great company to move from because of its name valueNice and kind people
review.cons: Cons – Does a terrible job of taking care of employees and their career
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Employee's growth and their goals matter as much as the company's growth and both help each other. Right now the management is ONLY focused on the company's growth.

review.title: “Great place”
review.pros: Pros – Great place to work at.
review.cons: Cons – no cons really other than management have to listen to their employees.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Listen to your staff

review.title: “Micromanaged to death, miserable politics--like high school.”
review.pros: Pros – High profile clients and high profile work. Good salary and half-decent benefits package. Lots of young people and parties--if you're into that.
review.cons: Cons – Upper management feels the need to constantly tout the same R/GA success stories to their employees, trying to reassure them that they, too, will eventually get to work on "their" Nike+... but that never happens. Creative leadership is mostly "old" R/GAers who have just stayed put and been promoted by seniority (and plenty of politicking) rather than earning it with skill. Long, long, long work hours for projects barely supported by project managers and account people.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Clear out deadwood! Don't just promote those who hang around long enough, and fire employees who haven't met their side of the bargain. Most of all, though, fire CLIENTS who are making your team's lives miserable.

review.title: “Horrible”
review.pros: Pros – Good clients. Nice office space and locationThat's really all!
review.cons: Cons – Horribly mismanagedTerrible work life balanceLeadership team have no integrity.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Sack the London management

review.title: “R/GA: Innovative and Hard-working”
review.pros: Pros – Smart people. Great work environment. Innovative work.
review.cons: Cons – Highly politicized environment, very hard working.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – none.

review.title: “Place to do your best work - but you'll pay for it”
review.pros: Pros – A good place to do groundbreaking digital work with a lot of reach
review.cons: Cons – Feels like a sweatshop sometimes
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Take better care of employees, retain key talent. Also, focus on either preserving the old culture or creating a new one - the limbo created by the unprecedented growth is numbing.

review.title: “Fast paced, innovative thinkers, large agency”
review.pros: Pros – Exceptionally bright coworkers, great clients
review.cons: Cons – It's a large agency, not extremely collaborative

review.title: “Get in bed with the right people and you'll be fine”
review.pros: Pros – Great reputation when you go to other placesSome very cool brands have been therecoffee barpockets of very talented people
review.cons: Cons – if you don't kiss the right asses you won't get promotedpoor management structure - its easy to get lostquestionable rise to power of some people
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – People need small management groups to have someone responsible for their career development and to be their champion in a large and unruly company atmosphere.

review.title: “A great place from the outside. A sweatshop on the inside.”
review.pros: Pros – The reputation of R/GA in the marketplace is great. They are fantastic at PR and that creates a certain image about the company and people who work there.
review.cons: Cons – First, it's a sweatshop. I had never worked that hard in my life. After sleeping in the office for two weeks, I went to my boss to ask for 1 or 2 comp days for the people on the team. The answer was simply "no."Second: titles are so inflated. Someone who was a mediocre art director at one shop went to R/GA to become an Executive Creative Director at R/GA (yes, ECD - they have like 40 ECDs in NY alone).Third, the management layer is so think that if you are joining the company, you are just one of the hundreds of minions that rotate in and out.Fourth, the pay was horrible. Period.Finally, if you work at R/GA, you just accept the fact that you work FOR (not with) Bob Greenberg and to make HIM rich and famous, not you.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Bob has made more money (and fame) than he'll ever need. He needs to think about spreading that a bit more to his employees.

review.title: “Great place - as long as you don't want/need a life”
review.pros: Pros – The people are amazing and innovation, including crazy/different thinking, is encouraged. The environment is truly collaborative and creative. I learned so much and was able to try so many things while at R/GA.
review.cons: Cons – Working at R/GA is a lifestyle. The only thing in your life is R/GA. Since the people are great this isn't so bad except the work never ends. No matter where you are or what you are doing, you will have work to do.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Don't lose the unique R/GA personality as the company grows. Encourage employees to take a break and allow space/time for things outside of work. When not at work, allow employees some time to turn off their phones, ignore their email and go off the grid.

review.title: “R/GA a very innovative environment and some really talented people.”
review.pros: Pros – Some very very talented people. It is a very collaborative and egalitarian environment. Company is starting to grow its conceptional/marketing (versus design) prowess and making strides.
review.cons: Cons – Output of work is not consistent and usually either very good or very bad. Varies depending on whether you get the "A" team or leadership is paying attention. Teams (especially creative) can get very large with no one "on first" making final calls, until up against the deadline. Drives a lot of doing-over at the last minute. If I were a client I'd be concerned about this driving up my fees.They are still a very production-driven shop with many of the senior executives not really fully on board with the migration to marketing/advertising work. So there are camps, which makes for mixed signals from leadership sometimes (even though from the very top it may be clear)
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Company is too large now to be just "people-driven," it needs process improvement and more structure for its current size and in order to continue to grow.
